thread.title: Brexit is not irreversible so don't let anyone tell you otherwise, says Mike Kelly
thread.title_full: Brexit is not irreversible so don't let anyone tell you otherwise, says Mike Kelly

author: Mike Kelly
title: Brexit is not irreversible so don't let anyone tell you otherwise, says Mike Kelly
text:
News Opinion Brexit is not irreversible so don't let anyone tell you otherwise, says Mike Kelly If the UK is truly a democracy anything can be changed if the public wants it to change Share Prime Minister Theresa May in the cabinet signing the Article 50 letter (Photo: PA) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Prime Minister Theresa May was pictured last week in Downing Street, pen poised, Union Jack visible to her side, signing the letter to the European Union telling it of the UK’s intention to trigger Article 50. 
The video version, should it ever appear, will no doubt have Jerusalem for a backing track. 
May might as well have been doing her lottery numbers for the odds of her winning the latest rollover jackpot are about as long as Brexit working out well for Britain. 
It’s like jumping out of a plane flying at 30,000 ft without a parachute, your only hope of survival being to land in a hayrick. 
Well, at least it was us who chose to jump is the thinking, except in the case of Brexit, the country was only 51.9% convinced it should. 
It’s been sold as Britain reclaiming control. But by who and of what? 
On Thursday came the chilling answer when Brexit ‘supremo’ David Davis said that up to 1,000 laws will be introduced through “statutory instruments”. Brexit Secretary David Davis 
This means, as Davis admitted, that many of these laws would not face proper debate. In other words the country hasn’t regained control, it has just been handed it over to the executive without full scrutiny of the House of Commons. 
I’m not the only one who suspects the biggest victim when laws go through on the nod will be workers’ rights - such as they are now - closely followed by the environment. 
When the UK joined the EU in 1973, it was dubbed the ‘dirty man of Europe’ because of its out of control pollution. 
With the influence of climate change deniers in the right wing press and the Tory habit of ditching ‘red tape’ - ie regulations - to the benefit of its supporters, expect Lindisfarne’s Fog on the Tyne to make a comeback. 
But to worry about all these things is to be a bad lose or to be doing Britain down. Those who were - and still are - against Brexit are supposed to suck it in and get over it. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
